creator: parikshit@email.com
text:
I recently downloaded the new Apache2.0.40 binary. I already was running the 
1.3.x binary. I installed the new 2.x and then uninstalled the 1.3.x. 
I tried to use the Menu to start the the apache server but it just fails. I 
looked into the error logs but that shows:
[Mon Sep 09 16:24:40 2002] [notice] Parent: Created child process 1256
[Mon Sep 09 16:24:40 2002] [notice] Child 1256: Child process is running
[Mon Sep 09 16:24:40 2002] [notice] Child 1256: Acquired the start mutex.
[Mon Sep 09 16:24:40 2002] [notice] Child 1256: Starting 250 worker threads.
[Mon Sep 09 16:25:03 2002] [notice] Parent: Received shutdown signal -- 
Shutting down the server.
[Mon Sep 09 16:25:03 2002] [notice] Child 1256: Exit event signaled. Child 
process is ending.
[Mon Sep 09 16:25:04 2002] [notice] Child 1256: Released the start mutex
[Mon Sep 09 16:25:05 2002] [notice] Child 1256: Waiting for 250 worker threads 
to exit.
[Mon Sep 09 16:25:08 2002] [notice] Child 1256: All worker threads have exited.
[Mon Sep 09 16:25:08 2002] [notice] Child 1256: Child process is exiting
[Mon Sep 09 16:25:08 2002] [notice] Parent: Child process exited successfully.

I then tried to run just the Apache.exe by double clicking on the file and the 
server startsup just fine and I am able to connect.

Let me know if you need anymore information.

Thanks,

Pari.

The actual error on why Apache wasn't starting was found when I looked up the 
Windows Event Log. The server failed due to parsing error of httpd.conf file.
The problem is that I have NFS mounted file system on my Windows box. These are 
mounted as different directories. Apache on my machine is installed in my C: 
drive, which is a local PC drive. In order for the Apache server to serve the 
files from these other mounts name E:/ and G:/ I added a few <Directory> 
directives to the httpd.conf file. This is the change that I did:
Alias /pari/ "G:/opt/var/files/"
            
             <Directory "G:/opt/var/files/">
                    Options Indexes MultiViews
                    AllowOverride None
                    Order allow,deny
                    Allow from all
    </Directory>

On seeing this the Apache server fails and reports:
<Directory "G:/opt/var/files/"> path is invalid. 
I know the G: drive is mounted properly and I can access this same directory by 
using a 'cmd' window and typing "G:\opt\var\file".

I know this was working in the previous Apache1.3.x version that I had 
installed. But from the time I installed the Apache2.0.x, this directory 
directive is failing.

Thanks,

Pari.
creator: parikshit@email.com
slive@apache.org
text:
[This is a mass bug update.]
This bug reports a problem in an older version of Apache 2.
Could you please update to the most recent version and see
if you can reproduce this problem.  If the bug still exists,
please update the bug with the latest version number.  If 
the bug no longer exists, please close the bug report.

Sorry for this impersonal response, but we get many more bug
reports than our volunteers can keep up with.
Thanks for using Apache!

creator: wrowe@apache.org
text:
If you hadn't uninstalled or stopped Apache 1.3, Apache 2.0 could not install
  it's service because no ports were available.

creator: parikshit@email.com
text:
I installed the latest 2.043 Version of Apache. The problem still persist.
However, if I don't use the event monitor utility and simply manually click on 
the /Apache Group/Apache2/bin/Apache.exe the server starts up I can view all 
the NFS mounted Alias directories.

Just explained to you why the install failed.  Not a bug.

  See http://httpd.apache.org/docs-2.0/platform/win_service.html
  for "how to" install the Apache2 service manually.

  Closing <again>.  Please do not reopen.
creator: wrowe@apache.org

text:
Listen out to this first before u are in a rush to close this bug again:

When I try starting it via the Service Start option, it fails saying that the 
following:
"Windows could not start the Apache2 on Local Computer. For more information, 
review the System Event Log. If this is not-Miscrosoft service, contact the 
service vendor, and refer to service-specific error code 1."

So then I go to the Event Logs and look into the System Log and see the 
following:
"The Apache2 service terminated with service-specific error 1. "

Then I look into the Application Log inside the Event Viewer and see two 
entries and they are the following:
1.
"The Apache service named  reported the following error:
>>> Syntax error on line 475 of C:/Program Files/Apache 
Group/Apache2/conf/httpd.conf:  "

2.
"The Apache service named  reported the following error:
>>> <Directory "E:/Test/Monkey/"> path is invalid.  "

Now E:\ is  valid NFS mounted drive on my machine and I can reach it and 
retrieve all the files. 

If I remove this Directory Alias from the httpd.conf file APache starts up 
WITHOUT any problem. But the moment I put it back in it fails.

Now if leave the service part and keep the same httpd.conf file which has the 
NFS mounted E:\ drive files and just to to the C:\Program Files\Apache 
Group\Apache2\bin directory and just click on the Apache.exe executable, it 
launches a command window and the webserver starts up and I am able to view all 
the E:\ drive files from a browser.

I hope I have presented enough clarification on this BUG! I don't want to be 
pointed again to that old documentation link that only talks about the 1.3.1 
release. Again I am running the 2.0.43 Apache binary. 

Thanks and I hope to get a resolution on it soon.
creator: parikshit@email.com
slive@apache.org
text:
Very likely a configuration error.  See specifically
http://httpd.apache.org/docs-2.0/platform/win_service.html#account

creator: c@rmen.ca
text:
I had this error with the following conf:

<Directory "c:/foo/bar">
    Options Indexes MultiViews
    AllowOverride None
    Order allow,deny
    Allow from all
</Directory>

c:/foo/bar existed, but it was created by cygwin.  I did the following in 
windows explorer:

- renamed bar to bar.old
- created new folder "bar" in "foo"
- copied the contents of bar.old to bar
- deleted bar.old

Then Apache restarted OK.

Please note that you may be able to see E: as a user so you may see that
E:/Test/Monkey/ is a valid directory but Apache runs as a service. It is often
that service doesn't see the NFS mounted directory what user see that.

Try :
C:> runas /user:Administrator cmd.exe
provide password

C:>dir E:\Test\Monkey\

Can you still view the directory.

Another approach is to write a test service and try to access E:\Test\Monkey\
directory
creator: basant.kukreja@sun.com
